content: I like option #1 a lot, especially with the subtle styling. #2 works for me too. I'm little wary of #3. I agree with the premise that mostly admins care about the version number, but I think it's unnecessary friction for non-admin users reporting bugs to have to ask their admin to get the version number.
@Steve Howell I think non-admin users still have access to admin settings.

I like the idea of having a version number on an About page, but I don't actually know where this page is. There's an About link at the bottom of the user documentation page, but it goes to https://chat.zulip.org/hello/.

https://chat.zulip.org/about/

at the bottom of this page
it would actually end up on the page that you linked to too, because that footer is shared with both pages
There is a very similar footer with a link at the bottom of /hello, but it just goes back to itself.
actually same thing with the page that i linked to
Yeah that's just the common portico (logged-out pages) template. We're probably going to redo it soon :)

I like all three of them. Version 1 would be most visible as people click settings a lot more than being in a particular part of the settings or the about page. So version 3 is probably not necessary.
And some users get excited about updates so if they see the version number change start exploring ;-)
I vote for the settings page (or maybe the about page) -- I don't think this is something most users will need (or need to think about) very often?
I would put it in the about page for now, but maybe in the text rather than the footer that's on every page?

currently, page_params doesn't get passed into the about page because its generated in the home.py. do we want to create a separate view for the about page to bring in the zulip_version data? the about page example I have up is just an example with the version number hardcoded in. I was hoping everyone would pick #1 haha. maybe a good time to do #3853 then?
I think you could add that specific value to zerver/context_processors.py
